podcast.description: Tune in every weekday for quick reports and commentaries on the world of science&mdash;it&#039;ll just take a minute

podcast_episode.title: The Kavli Prize Presents: Building Materials From The Bottom Up [Sponsored]
podcast_episode.name: The Kavli Prize Presents: Building Materials From The Bottom Up [Sponsored]
podcast_episode.description: Chad Mirkin, recipient of the 2024 Kavli Prize in Nanoscience, has spent his career exploring the possibilities of creating and inventing materials at the nanoscale. This podcast was produced for The Kavli Prize by Scientific American Custom Media, a division separate from the magazine’s board of editors. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
podcast_episode.filename: 60-Second Science - The Kavli Prize Presents: Building Materials From The Bottom Up [Sponsored].

podcast_episode.title: Astronauts Can Drink More Recycled Pee Than Ever, and You Can Still Catch the Plague
podcast_episode.name: Astronauts Can Drink More Recycled Pee Than Ever, and You Can Still Catch the Plague
podcast_episode.description: We commemorate the 55th anniversary of the Apollo 11 mission, dive into NASA’s groundbreaking Mars habitat simulation and discuss the innovative ​​“stillsuits” designed to recycle astronaut pee and how they could enhance spacewalks. Plus, we discuss the record-breaking Hurricane Beryl and its implications for climate change policies, and a surprising case of the plague in Colorado.  Recommended reading: – One Small Step Back in Time: Relive the Wonder of Apollo 11 – Why Hurricane Beryl Underwent Unprecedented Rapid Intensification Science Quickly is produced by Rachel Feltman, Fonda Mwangi, Kelso Harper, Madison Goldberg and Jeff DelViscio. This episode was hosted by Rachel Feltman. Our show is edited by Elah Feder, Alexa Lim, Madison Goldberg and Anaissa Ruiz Tejada, with fact-checking by Shayna Posses and Aaron Shattuck. The theme music was composed by Dominic Smith. E-mail us at sciencequickly@sciam.com if you have any questions, comments or ideas for stories we should cover! Discover something new every day: subscribe to Scientific American and sign up for Today in Science, our daily newsletter. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
podcast_episode.filename: 60-Second Science - Astronauts Can Drink More Recycled Pee Than Ever, and You Can Still Catch the Plague.

podcast_episode.title: On Thin Ice: Contemplating Our Climate Future in Antarctica (Part 4)
podcast_episode.name: On Thin Ice: Contemplating Our Climate Future in Antarctica (Part 4)
podcast_episode.description: We’re at the end of the Nathaniel B. Palmer’s Antarctic expedition. The researchers onboard are returning sea ice and thousands of gallons of seawater. These samples will allow them to examine biogeochemical processes, some of which are linked to climate change. As the research vessel makes its way back to port, the scientists reflect on the future of our planet and the question of whether the ice in Antarctica will always be around for sampling. Listen to the first three episodes of this series:  – Glacial Melting Could Change the Chemistry of Antarctic Seawater  – Penguins and Ice Samples Make This Research Vessel Paradice – Life for Researchers on This Icebreaker Is Cold and Fulfilling E-mail us at sciencequickly@sciam.com if you have any questions, comments or ideas for stories we should cover! Discover something new every day: subscribe to Scientific American and sign up for Today in Science, our daily newsletter. Science Quickly is produced by Rachel Feltman, Fonda Mwangi, Kelso Harper, Madison Goldberg and Jeff DelViscio. This episode was hosted by journalist Sofia Moutinho. Our show is edited by Elah Feder, Alexa Lim, Madison Goldberg and Anaissa Ruiz Tejada, with fact-checking by Shayna Posses and Aaron Shattuck. The theme music was composed by Dominic Smith. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
podcast_episode.filename: 60-Second Science - On Thin Ice: Contemplating Our Climate Future in Antarctica (Part 4).

podcast_episode.filename: 60-Second Science - Saving the Last Truly Wild Horse.

podcast_episode.title: A Blast from Our Past and Plans for a Petrochemical-Free Future
podcast_episode.name: A Blast from Our Past and Plans for a Petrochemical-Free Future
podcast_episode.description:
We’re looking at our reporting—from 100 years ago. In 1924 Scientific American’s pages were bemoaning traffic, waste management and pests. They were also praising the by-products of coal tar and those substances’ use in household items. While the record is clear on the toxicity of fossil fuels to our environment and our health, demand for fossil-fuel-based “petrochemical” products such as plastic is only increasing. Host Rachel Feltman advises on how to avoid petrochemicals in our everyday products. Plus, we take a lighthearted look at a telepathy study also featured in one of our 1924 issues. 
Recommended reading: The Gas Industry Is Gaslighting the Public about Climate Change Renewable Power Set to Surpass Coal Globally by 2025
E-mail us at sciencequickly@sciam.com if you have any questions, comments or ideas for stories we should cover! Discover something new every day: subscribe to Scientific American and sign up for Today in Science, our daily newsletter.  Science Quickly is produced by Rachel Feltman, Fonda Mwangi, Kelso Harper, Madison Goldberg and Jeff DelViscio. This episode was hosted by Rachel Feltman. Our show is edited by Elah Feder, Alexa Lim, Madison Goldberg and Anaissa Ruiz Tejada, with fact-checking by Shayna Posses and Aaron Shattuck. The theme music was composed by Dominic Smith.

podcast_episode.name: The Supreme Court Plays Hot Potato with Idaho’s Abortion Restrictions, and NASA Plays It Safe with Starliner
podcast_episode.filename: 60-Second Science - The Supreme Court Plays Hot Potato with Idaho’s Abortion Restrictions, and NASA Plays It Safe with Starliner.

podcast_episode.title: On Thin Ice: Life Onboard an Antarctic Icebreaker (Part 3)
podcast_episode.name: On Thin Ice: Life Onboard an Antarctic Icebreaker (Part 3)
podcast_episode.description: Life onboard the Nathaniel B. Palmer can be cramped and cold. Chaotic work schedules and changing time zones can be disorienting, and the isolation of Antarctica is hard to handle. Research, routine and a mock trial with the god of the sea help these scientists stay grounded. Stay tuned for the fourth and final episode of this Friday Fascination: researchers reflect on the emotional toll of witnessing climate change’s impact on Antarctica. E-mail us at sciencequickly@sciam.com if you have any questions, comments or ideas for stories we should cover! podcast_episode.title: How to Stay Cool during Record-Breaking Heat Waves
podcast_episode.name: How to Stay Cool during Record-Breaking Heat Waves
podcast_episode.description:
Summers are getting hotter, with heat waves that last longer and occur more often. That makes it even more important to communicate the risks of heat to vulnerable groups and keep communities and individuals cool. Sustainability editor Andrea Thompson explains why it feels hotter than ever and how to keep yourself and your community safe in the summer heat. 
Recommended reading: This Isn’t Your Grandparents’ Summer Heat How Some Common Medications Can Make People More Vulnerable to Heat
E-mail us at sciencequickly@sciam.com if you have any questions, comments or ideas for stories we should cover! Discover something new every day: subscribe to Scientific American and sign up for Today in Science, our daily newsletter.  Science Quickly is produced by Rachel Feltman, Fonda Mwangi, Kelso Harper, Madison Goldberg and Jeff DelViscio. This episode was hosted by Rachel Feltman, with special guest Andrea Thompson. Our show is edited by Elah Feder, Alexa Lim, Madison Goldberg and Anaissa Ruiz Tejada, with fact-checking by Shayna Posses and Aaron Shattuck. The theme music was composed by Dominic Smith.

podcast_episode.filename: 60-Second Science - How to Stay Cool during Record-Breaking Heat Waves.

podcast_episode.title: Your Penis Might Be Full of Microplastics, and The Seine is Definitely Full of Bacteria
podcast_episode.name: Your Penis Might Be Full of Microplastics, and The Seine is Definitely Full of Bacteria
podcast_episode.description:
Microplastics are everywhere—and we mean everywhere. These pesky plastic pollutants have been found in penis tissue, testicles, breast milk and blood. They’ve turned up in Antarctic snow, in the clouds above Mount Fuji, inside deep-sea creatures and near the top of Mount Everest. In Paris Olympic ambitions for the Seine’s are being complicated by bacteria. Far above Earth, the Starliner spacecraft faced a rocky road to the International Space Station (ISS). Starliner’s return to Earth is being delayed as Boeing and NASA officials take a look at the leaks and thruster failures that occurred during its journey to the ISS. Recommended reading: Microplastics Linked to Heart Attack, Stroke and Death The Physics of Breakdancing, a New Olympic Sport 
E-mail us at sciencequickly@sciam.com if you have any questions, comments or ideas for stories we should cover! Discover something new every day: subscribe to Scientific American and sign up for Today in Science, our daily newsletter.  Science Quickly is produced by Rachel Feltman, Fonda Mwangi, Kelso Harper, Madison Goldberg and Jeff DelViscio. This episode was hosted by Rachel Feltman. Our show is edited by Elah Feder, Alexa Lim, Madison Goldberg and Anaissa Ruiz Tejada, with fact-checking by Shayna Posses and Aaron Shattuck. The theme music was composed by Dominic Smith. Learn more about your ad choices. Visit megaphone.fm/adchoices
podcast_episode.filename: 60-Second Science - Your Penis Might Be Full of Microplastics, and The Seine is Definitely Full of Bacteria.

podcast.name: Plays Well with Others
podcast.description: From Creative Commons, a podcast about the art and science of collaboration. With a focus on the tools, techniques, and mechanics of collaboration, we explore how today's most interesting collaborators are making new things, solving old problems, and getting things done — together. Hosted by Creative Commons CEO Ryan Merkley.

podcast.name: Trace
podcast.description: An investigative podcast hosted by ABC journalist Rachael Brown, Trace examines the fractures in Australia's criminal justice system, and the decades-long ripples they have caused.
podcast.copyright: Copyright 2024, Australian Broadcasting Corporation. All right reserved.

podcast_episode.title: S1 BONUS | A million-dollar reward
podcast_episode.name: S1 BONUS | A million-dollar reward
podcast_episode.description: <p>Victoria Police is set to announce a one million dollar reward for information that finally solves the case of Maria James, who was murdered in the back of her bookshop 44 years ago. And for the first time in seven years of investigating this case, police grant an interview to Rachael Brown.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 BONUS | A million-dollar reward.

podcast_episode.title: S1 Bonus | Maria James inquest finding
podcast_episode.name: S1 Bonus | Maria James inquest finding
podcast_episode.description: <p>A Victorian Coroner has failed to name a killer in the 1980 cold case of Maria James. Her sons are devastated. But there's still hope, in leads yet to be chased by police.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 Bonus | Maria James inquest finding.

podcast_episode.title: S1 Bonus | The Inquest
podcast_episode.name: S1 Bonus | The Inquest
podcast_episode.description: <p>The new coronial inquest into the murder of Maria James has wrapped up. Will the Coroner be able to name her killer? And of the police exhibits that haven't disappeared, what DNA testing can be done? This episode nears us closer to the end of the James brothers' 41-year-fight for answers for their mum.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 Bonus | The Inquest.

podcast_episode.title: S1 Bonus | Breakthrough in Maria James cold case
podcast_episode.name: S1 Bonus | Breakthrough in Maria James cold case
podcast_episode.description: <p>The discovery of a police exhibit - thought to be missing for around three decades - could finally help unmask the killer in the 1980 cold case of Maria James.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 Bonus | Breakthrough in Maria James cold case.

podcast_episode.title: S2 BONUS — The Price
podcast_episode.name: S2 BONUS — The Price
podcast_episode.description: <p>The Royal Commission has released its final report into defence lawyer turned police informer Nicola Gobbo.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 BONUS — The Price.

podcast_episode.title: S2 08 | End game
podcast_episode.name: S2 08 | End game
podcast_episode.description: <p>We reveal the story of Nicola Gobbo's audacious bid to return to Australia.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 08 | End game.

podcast_episode.title: S2 07 | Reckoning
podcast_episode.name: S2 07 | Reckoning
podcast_episode.description: <p>Everything unravels, for Nicola Gobbo and Victoria Police. Their secret is out.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 07 | Reckoning.

podcast_episode.title: S2 06 | Whatever it takes
podcast_episode.name: S2 06 | Whatever it takes
podcast_episode.description: <p>Nicola hits rock bottom, but Victoria Police wants her to take on a new role ... as a witness.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 06 | Whatever it takes.

podcast_episode.title: S2 05 | Glittering prize
podcast_episode.name: S2 05 | Glittering prize
podcast_episode.description: <p>Nicola wants to be the best source ever, and she leads police to the biggest target of all: the mafia. Her double life is getting riskier, but she can't stop. This episode charts an addiction and a crash.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 05 | Glittering prize.

podcast_episode.title: S2 04 | Rubicon
podcast_episode.name: S2 04 | Rubicon
podcast_episode.description: <p>Nicola crosses the point of no return and becomes a police informer. She'll represent clients, while passing on the underworld's secrets to Victoria Police.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 04 | Rubicon.

podcast_episode.title: S2 03 | The darkest night
podcast_episode.name: S2 03 | The darkest night
podcast_episode.description: <p>A drug house burglary smells of police corruption and a police informer is executed.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 03 | The darkest night.

podcast_episode.title: S2 02 | One of the crew
podcast_episode.name: S2 02 | One of the crew
podcast_episode.description: <p>As the gangland war explodes, both police and criminals start questioning Nicola's allegiances. Where do her loyalties lie?</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 02 | One of the crew.

podcast_episode.title: S2 01 | Nicola
podcast_episode.name: S2 01 | Nicola
podcast_episode.description: <p>We meet Nicola Gobbo in a secret location, in hiding, now that her double life as a police informer is out, and she begins telling us her full story.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S2 01 | Nicola.

podcast_episode.title: INTRODUCING Trace season 2 - The Informer
podcast_episode.name: INTRODUCING Trace season 2 - The Informer
podcast_episode.description: <p>Lawyer Nicola Gobbo represented some of Australia's most dangerous criminals, all the while secretly working as a police informer. Why did she do it?</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - INTRODUCING Trace season 2 - The Informer.

podcast_episode.title: S1 07 | Hope
podcast_episode.name: S1 07 | Hope
podcast_episode.description: <p>More than a year on from their plea for a new coronial inquest, the James brothers get a decision.</p><p>Will they finally get answers to the burning questions they've carried for 38 years about the murder of their mother?</p><p>And what about those items Trace has been given that might have DNA on them?</p><p>Can they identify the killer?</p><p>We take them to one of the world's best DNA labs, with some of the most sensitive equipment, to find out.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 07 | Hope.

podcast_episode.title: S1 06 | Limbo
podcast_episode.name: S1 06 | Limbo
podcast_episode.description: <p>New evidence has been found. So can police test it for a trace of the killer? What happened to crucial documents? And a new confession.</p><p>It is nearly a year since the James brothers applied for a new coronial inquest into their mum's murder, but the case hangs in legal limbo. </p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 06 | Limbo.

podcast_episode.title: S1 05 | Wait
podcast_episode.name: S1 05 | Wait
podcast_episode.description: <p>The fall-out from major revelations in the Maria James cold-case continue, as her sons make a desperate plea to the Coroner. </p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 05 | Wait.

podcast_episode.title: S1 04 | DNA
podcast_episode.name: S1 04 | DNA
podcast_episode.description: <p>There's a major break in the case, as Trace uncovers a police bungle in the murder of Maria James. But it only serves to throw up more questions than answers, as the James brothers continue their desperate search for justice.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 04 | DNA.

podcast_episode.title: S1 03 | Sins
podcast_episode.name: S1 03 | Sins
podcast_episode.description: <p>A second person of interest emerges within the church. Rachael Brown investigates their past and discovers a dark and disturbing history. </p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 03 | Sins.

podcast_episode.title: BONUS | How your leads are helping the investigation
podcast_episode.name: BONUS | How your leads are helping the investigation
podcast_episode.description: <p>Since Trace was first released, the ABC has received over 50 emails from the community with leads and tip offs. In this bonus update, reporter Rachael Brown follows up with two women who got in touch to say they saw men acting suspiciously around Maria's bookshop at the time of her murder. Send us your tips: <a href="mailto:trace@abc.net.au">trace@abc.net.au</a></p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - BONUS | How your leads are helping the investigation.

podcast_episode.title: S1 02 | Confessions
podcast_episode.name: S1 02 | Confessions
podcast_episode.description: <p>Rachael Brown's investigation into the death of Maria James turns to the local Church, and Rachael tracks down a new witness who saw someone covered in blood around the time of Maria's death.</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 02 | Confessions.

podcast_episode.title: S1 01 | Bookshop murder
podcast_episode.name: S1 01 | Bookshop murder
podcast_episode.description: <p>On a winter morning in June 1980, Maria James turned to her son Mark and looked him in the eyes. "If anything happens to me, look after your brother." Later that day she was found stabbed to death at the back of her suburban Melbourne bookshop. </p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - S1 01 | Bookshop murder.

podcast_episode.title: INTRODUCING: Trace, series 1 — Bookshop Murder
podcast_episode.name: INTRODUCING: Trace, series 1 — Bookshop Murder
podcast_episode.description: <p>June, 1980, suburban Melbourne: Mother of two Maria James is stabbed to death in the back of her bookshop. Her killer has never been found. Was it a scorned lover? A random stranger? Or was Maria's murder tied up in the sins of the Catholic Church?</p>
podcast_episode.filename: Trace - INTRODUCING: Trace, series 1 — Bookshop Murder.
